claim: Examples of pitch-catch, pulse-echo, thickness mode and AE detection PWAS modes for SHM are depicted in Figure 1.
title: Figure 1.
caption: Possible uses of piezoelectric wafer active sensors (PWASs) in SHM applications; (a) pitch-catch; (b) pulse-echo; (c) thickness mode; (d) impact/AE detection [3].

claim: A diagram of the PWAS pitch-catch experiment is shown in Figure 2, where T represents the transmitting sensor and R represents the receiving sensors.
title: Figure 2.
caption: Diagram of pitch-catch experimentation where T represents the transmitting PWAS and R represents the receiving PWAS.

Diagram of pitch-catch experimentation where T represents the transmitting PWAS and R represents the receiving PWAS.Using the numbering convention pictured in Figure 2, it is expected that due to the symmetry of instrumentation, the waveforms received at PWASs 4, 2 and 1 when PWAS 3 is transmitting should be the similar to the waveforms received at PWASs 3, 1 and 2 when PWAS 4 is transmitting.
title: Figure 2.
caption: Diagram of pitch-catch experimentation where T represents the transmitting PWAS and R represents the receiving PWAS.

Experimental setup for pitch-catch experimentation.Pitch-catch experimentation was first performed on a pristine specimen instrumented with 4 PWAS, as previously discussed and shown in Figure 2.

title: Figure 2.

caption: Specimen instrumented with two pristine PWASs, one broken PWAS, one PWAS with tape beneath the bonding layer and one PWAS with grease beneath the bonding layer.

title: Figure 6.
caption: Experimental setup for conducting EMIS testing.

claim:
Experimental Results: Discussion of Results Obtained
On a specimen instrumented with four pristine PWASs, as pictured in Figure 2, the first excitation function used in pitch-catch experimentation is the smooth-delta function.
title: Figure 2.
caption: Diagram of pitch-catch experimentation where T represents the transmitting PWAS and R represents the receiving PWAS.

claim: Seen in Figure 15, two fixed distances in placement of the sensors are the distance between PWAS 1 and PWAS 2 and the distance between PWASs 3 and 4, or the distance between the two inner and two outer PWASs.
title: Figure 15.
caption: Comparison of perfect and imperfect placement of PWAS on specimen.

claim: Figure 15 depicts the difference between imperfect and perfect placement.
title: Figure 15.
caption: Comparison of perfect and imperfect placement of PWAS on specimen.

claim:
Open in a new tab
Comparison of perfect and imperfect placement of PWAS on specimen.After exploring the use of the pitch-catch method for the determination of PWAS instrumentation quality, pitch-catch testing was performed on a specimen with defective instrumentation, pictured in Figure 5, to investigate the effects of defects on the PWAS response.
title: Figure 5.
caption: Specimen instrumented with two pristine PWASs, one broken PWAS, one PWAS with tape beneath the bonding layer and one PWAS with grease beneath the bonding layer.
